claude.translation: That the bodies of animals are compounded from hot and cold and dry and moist, and that the share of each in the mixture is not equal in all cases, has been sufficiently demonstrated by the ancients, by the best of both philosophers and physicians. We too have stated what is reasonable concerning these matters in another work, in which we examined the elements according to Hippocrates. But now, which is the next step after that work, I shall proceed in this present treatise to discover all the differences of mixtures, both how many they are and of what sort when divided according to species and genera, making my beginning from an explanation of the terms. For whenever they say that bodies are mixed from hot and cold and dry and moist, they assert that one must understand these in their extreme form, that is, the elements themselves—air and fire and water and earth. But whenever they say that an animal or plant is hot or cold or dry or moist, it is no longer in the same way. For no animal can be extremely hot like fire nor extremely moist like water. Similarly, neither can it be cold or dry in the extreme, but the designations arise from what predominates in the mixture: we call that moist in which there is a greater share of moisture, and that dry in which there is a greater share of dryness; and likewise we call that hot in which the hot predominates over the cold, and that cold in which the cold predominates over the hot. This, then, is the usage of the terms.

gemini.translation: That the bodies of living beings are mixed from the hot and the cold and the dry and the wet, and that the portion of all of these in the mixture is not equal, has been sufficiently demonstrated by ancient men, by the best of both philosophers and physicians; and what is fitting concerning them has also been stated by us in another treatise, in which we examined the elements according to Hippocrates. But now, in this treatise, I shall proceed to the topic that follows upon that one, namely, to discover all the differences of the mixtures—how many and of what sort they are, when divided according to species and genera—making my beginning from an explanation of the terms. For whenever they say that bodies are mixed from the hot and the cold and the dry and the wet, they say one must understand this to mean those things that are so in the extreme—that is, the elements themselves: air and fire and water and earth. But whenever they say that a living being or a plant is hot or cold or dry or wet, it is no longer in the same way. For no living being can be extremely hot like fire, nor extremely wet like water. And likewise, neither cold nor dry in the ultimate degree, but the designations arise from that which predominates in the mixture: we call 'wet' that in which there is a greater portion of wetness, and 'dry' that in which there is a greater portion of dryness; and so also 'hot' is that in which the hot predominates over the cold, and 'cold' is that in which the cold predominates over the hot. Such, then, is the usage of the terms.

openai.translation: That the bodies of animals are composed by mixture from the hot, the cold, the dry, and the moist, and that the share of each in the mixture is not equal, has been sufficiently demonstrated by men of old, both by philosophers and by the best physicians; and I too have set forth the probable considerations concerning these matters in another treatise, in which we examined the elements according to Hippocrates. Now, as what follows upon that, I shall in this work investigate all the differences of temperaments—how many they are and of what sort, when distinguished by species and by genera—beginning with an explanation of the terms. For whenever they say that bodies are mixed from the hot and the cold and the dry and the moist, they maintain that we must understand these in their extreme form, that is, the elements themselves—air, fire, water, and earth. But whenever they say that an animal or a plant is hot or cold or dry or moist, they do not speak in the same way. For no living creature can be in the extreme hot like fire or in the extreme moist like water; nor likewise can it be to the utmost degree cold or dry. Rather, the appellations arise from what predominates in the mixture: we call that moist in which there is a greater share of moisture, and that dry in which there is a greater share of dryness; likewise, we call that hot in which the hot preponderates over the cold, and that cold in which the cold preponderates over the hot. Such is the usage of the terms.

claude.translation: And this is what most produces the diseased condition of autumn, the irregularity of its mixture. Therefore it has not been correctly stated that it is cold and dry, for it is not cold when considered in itself, as winter is, but only colder than summer when compared to it. Nor indeed is it uniformly well-tempered, as spring is, but in this very respect it differs most from that season, because it does not possess an equal temperament and uniformity throughout. For it is much hotter at midday than at dawn and evening. As regards moisture and dryness, it is not precisely intermediate, as spring is, but inclines toward the drier. Yet it falls short of summer in this respect too, though not as much as it does in heat. It is clear, therefore, that autumn should not be described simply in the way those people describe it, as being cold and dry. For it is neither of these in the extreme, but the dry prevails in it over the moist, and it might justly be called dry in this respect, but in the difference relating to heat and cold it is mixed from both and irregular. Consequently, if they are eager to distribute the four combinations of mixtures among the four seasons, let them know that they have wrongly assigned not only the mixture of moisture and heat to spring, but also coldness and dryness to autumn. And yet, even if it were granted that autumn is dry and cold, it would not be necessary that spring should straightaway be moist and hot.

gemini.translation: And this is indeed what makes autumn most productive of disease: the irregularity of its temperament. Therefore, it has been incorrectly stated that it is cold and dry. For it is not cold when considered in and of itself, as winter is, but when compared with summer, it is colder than it. Moreover, it is not evenly well-tempered, as spring is, but it is in this very point that it differs most from that season, in that it does not possess a good temperament and evenness that are constant throughout. For it is much hotter at midday than at dawn and evening. And with respect to wetness and dryness, it is not, to be sure, precisely intermediate, as spring is, but inclines toward the drier. And in this respect too it falls short of summer, though certainly not by as much as it does in respect to heat. openai.translation: And this, indeed, is what makes autumn especially disease-producing: the irregularity of its temperament. It has not, then, been rightly called cold and dry, for it is not cold when considered in itself, as winter is, but only in comparison with summer is it the colder. Nor is it uniformly temperate, as spring is; rather, it differs above all from that season in this, that it does not maintain temperateness and uniformity equally throughout. For it is much warmer at midday than in the morning and evening. And as regards moisture and dryness, it is not exactly at the mean, as spring is, but inclines toward the drier. Even in this, however, it falls short of summer, though not to so great an extent as in respect of heat. It is clear, then, that autumn too is not to be described simply, as those people say, as being cold and dry. For strictly speaking it is neither; but in it the dry prevails over the moist, and in this respect it could rightly be called dry, whereas in the differentiation according to heat and cold it is a mixture of both and irregular. Therefore, if they are eager to assign the four pairings of temperaments to the four seasons, let them recognize that they have wrongly ascribed to spring a temperament of moisture and warmth, and likewise to autumn one of coldness and dryness. And yet, even if this too were conceded to be dry and cold, it would not of necessity at once follow that spring is moist and warm.

claude.translation: In these cases, comparison with a human being is comparison with something of the same species, while comparison with a bee or an ant is comparison with something of the same genus, and likewise also with any plant whatsoever. For this genus is higher than the animal, just as stone and iron and bronze are from genera still higher than this. Let such comparison in its entirety be called comparison with something of the same genus, for the sake of concise instruction, our only distinction in this matter being as follows: whenever some substance is said to be well-tempered in an absolute sense, and some other substance is drier and hotter and colder and moister than this, we here call "well-tempered" that which has come together from exactly equal contraries, and whatever falls short of this or exceeds it in some respect, we designate by the name of that which exceeds; but whenever we speak of a well-tempered plant or any animal whatsoever, we no longer in such an expression compare the contraries to one another in an absolute sense, but we make our reference to the nature of the plant or of the animal, saying, for instance, that a fig tree is well-tempered whenever it happens to be such as it is most fitting by nature for a fig tree to be, and again a dog and a pig and a horse and a human being, whenever each of these too is in the best condition of its own nature. And this very thing, being in the best condition of one's own nature, is judged by the activities. For indeed we say that both a plant and any animal whatsoever are in the best condition at that time when they perform their functions most excellently.

gemini.translation: Among these, however, comparing to a human being is a comparison to something of the same species, whereas comparing to a bee or an ant is a comparison to something of the same genus, and likewise also to any plant whatsoever. For this genus is higher than that of ‘animal’, just as, in turn, stone and iron and bronze belong to the genera above this one. Let this entire sort of comparison, at any rate, be called a comparison to something of the same genus for the sake of concise instruction, provided that we make only the following distinction within it: namely that, on the one hand, whenever some substance is spoken of as ‘well-tempered’ in an absolute sense, and some other substance as drier, hotter, colder, or wetter than it, we in this case call ‘well-tempered’ that which has come together from precisely equal opposites; on the other hand, whatever falls short of this standard and has an excess in some respect, we address by the name of that which is in excess. But whenever we speak of a ‘well-tempered’ plant or any animal whatsoever, in such an expression we no longer compare the opposites to one another in an absolute sense, but we make the reference to the nature of the plant or of the animal, speaking of a fig tree, for instance, as ‘well-tempered’ whenever it is of such a kind as the nature of a fig tree is most properly constituted, and, in turn, of a dog, a pig, a horse, and a human being whenever each of these, too, is in the best state of its own proper nature. And this very thing—being in the best state of one’s own proper nature—is judged by its activities. For indeed, we say that any plant or animal whatsoever is best disposed at the very time when it performs its activities most excellently.

openai.translation: In these cases, to compare with a human being is to compare with something of the same species, whereas to compare with a bee or an ant is to compare with something of the same genus—and likewise with any plant whatever. For this genus stands higher than “animal,” just as, moreover, stone, iron, and bronze too derive from the genera higher up. Let, then, for the sake of concise instruction, the whole of such comparison be called comparison to what is of the same genus, with only this distinction drawn within it by us: whenever a simple substance is called well-tempered, and another of the same kind is called drier, hotter, colder, or moister, here we call well-tempered that in which the contraries, having come together in exact equality, are balanced; whereas whatever falls short of this and has a preponderance in some respect we designate by the name of what preponderates. But whenever we say that a plant is well-tempered, or any animal whatsoever, we no longer, in such a statement, set the contraries simply against one another; rather, we make our reference to the nature of the plant or of the animal—saying, for example, that a fig tree is well-tempered, if it happens to be of the sort it most properly belongs to a fig tree’s nature to be; and likewise a dog, a pig, a horse, and a human being, whenever each of these has its own nature in the best condition. And this very fact of having one’s own nature in the best condition is judged by the activities. For we say that both a plant and any animal are in the best condition whenever they perform their activities most excellently.

claude.translation: All those parts, then, which are harder than the skin, such as bones and cartilages and horns and hairs and nails and ligaments and hooves and spurs, contain more of the dry element; but all those which are softer, such as blood and phlegm and fat and suet and marrow and brain and spinal cord, contain more of the moist than the dry. And indeed, by as much as the driest part of all in man exceeds the skin in hardness, by so much in turn does the moistest fall short of it. The discussion seems now somehow to be touching upon the most useful matters and to be teaching, on the one hand, that man is the most well-tempered not only of animals but of all other bodies whatsoever, and on the other hand, that among the parts in him the inner skin of the hand has precisely escaped all extremes. Let us therefore pause again at this point in the discussion and consider which man is best tempered of all, whom one must place in the middle both of the whole of substance and still more of men and other animals, like a certain standard and rule, and by comparing all others to him call them hot and cold and dry and moist. Many characteristics must converge together in such a man. For when examined in relation to the whole of substance, such a man must appear to be in the middle, and still more so in relation to men and animals. The common characteristics of all substance have been stated previously; but those characteristics as they exist among species of animals are judged by the perfection of the activity appropriate to each.

But the argument seems in a way already to be touching upon the most useful points themselves and to be teaching, at once that the human being is the most well-tempered not only of animals but also of all other bodies, and at the same time that, of the parts within him, the skin on the inside of the hand has precisely escaped all excesses. Let us therefore pause the argument here again and consider which human being is the best-tempered of all, whom it is necessary to place in the middle—with respect to the whole of substance, and even more so with respect to humans and other animals—as a kind of canon and standard, and, by comparing all others to this one, to call them hot and cold and dry and moist. For indeed, to one examining him in relation to the whole of substance, such a person must appear to be in the middle, and still more so in relation to humans and animals. Now, the characteristic marks common to all substance have been stated before; but those as they appear among the species of animals are judged by the perfection of the function proper to each.

openai.translation:
Accordingly, whatever parts are harder than the skin—bones, cartilages, horns, hairs, nails, ligaments, hoofs, and spurs—the dry element predominates in these; whereas those that are softer—blood, phlegm, adipose tissue, tallow, and marrow, both cerebral and spinal—have more of the moist than of the dry. And indeed, by just so much as the driest part in a human being exceeds the skin in hardness, by just so much, conversely, does the moistest fall short of it. The argument already seems in some way to be touching upon and teaching their most useful aspects—both that the human being is the most well-tempered not only of animals but of all other bodies as well, and that, among the parts in him, the inner skin of the hand has exactly escaped all extremes.

Let us then pause here again and examine which human being is of all most excellently tempered—whom one ought to set, with respect to the whole substance, and still more with respect to human beings and the other animals, in the mean; and, having set him as a kind of rule and standard, by comparing all the rest to him, to designate them as hot, cold, dry, and moist. Many criteria must converge upon this same point. For to one examining with reference to the whole of substance such a person should appear to be in the mean, and even more so with reference to human beings and to animals. The common criteria of the whole of substance have been stated above; but as they occur in the kinds of living beings, they are judged by the perfection of the activity appropriate to each.

Accordingly, whatever parts are harder than the skin—bones, cartilages, horns, hairs, nails, ligaments, hoofs, and spurs—the dry element predominates in these; whereas those that are softer—blood, phlegm, adipose tissue, tallow, and marrow, both cerebral and spinal—have more of the moist than of the dry. And indeed, by just so much as the driest part in a human being exceeds the skin in hardness, by just so much, conversely, does the moistest fall short of it. claude.translation: Again, from their activities, some say that the heat in children is strong because they both grow and desire and consume foods in greater quantity than is proportionate to their body. But others say that their growth occurs rather through moisture than through the strength of heat, and that in digestions they not only do not have an advantage but actually fall far short of those in their prime. For they say that vomiting of undigested foods occurs in them, as well as discharges that are fluid, rough, and lacking in proper humor. And if they desire more food, they say this has nothing to do with the strength of heat. For in the first place, animals do not desire food through an excess of heat, but quite the opposite, since the appetitive parts are being cooled; and secondly, because their nourishment is distributed not only for nutrition but also for growth, for this reason they require more food. Yet in all other activities children very clearly fall short of those in their prime. For they do not walk or run or carry burdens or in general perform any of the practical activities in the same way, and they say that both the senses and the thoughts reach the peak of excellence in those in their prime. In general, the one is still an incomplete animal, while the other is already complete. And in complete beings, they say, it is reasonable that the most active and most governing of the elements should prevail. Moreover, one can see that sleep occurs most frequently in children, but least in those in their prime.

claude.translation: All membranes are already drier than skin, just as indeed are the meninges around both the brain and the spinal cord; for these too are membranes. And furthermore all ligaments, to the extent that they are harder than skin, to that extent are they also drier. And tendons too, even if they are softer than ligaments, are at any rate manifestly harder than skin. Cartilages come after ligaments and are a body intermediate between both; some anatomists call this a neuro-cartilaginous ligament. This is a hard and cartilaginous ligament. Bone is the hardest of all things that skin covers, and of its projections, hair is the driest, then horn, then nails and hooves and spurs and beaks and all such parts as exist in each of the irrational animals. Of the humors, blood is the most useful and most proper. Of this, black bile is a kind of sediment and dregs; accordingly it is both colder and thicker than blood; yellow bile is much hotter, while phlegm is the coldest and most fluid of all things in the animal. The criterion for distinguishing this too is touch, just as Hippocrates also employed in his On the Nature of Man. But that it is cold, touch alone discerns; that it is also fluid, touch and sight and reasoning together discern—touch and sight because it appears such to each of them, and reasoning by determining that it became such not through abundance of heat, but through innate moisture.

claude.translation: For it has been demonstrated previously that in those who are aging all the parts become dry. In many people the skin becomes more shell-like than it should, having been excessively dried. In such a condition nothing can grow, as has also been agreed upon in the preceding discussion. Indeed, the inner parts of the hands, just as the lower parts of the feet, are hairless and bare due to the dryness and density of the tendon beneath them, which lies under the skin. But in those whose scalp does not reach the final stage of dryness, the hairs become weak and entirely white, which people call grey hairs—weak due to lack of their proper nourishment, and white because that which nourishes them is like a kind of mold of phlegm that has putrefied over time. For when the passage still remains, but the residue is small and viscous, and is weakly pushed forward by the heat, it undergoes something similar in this putrefaction. And indeed aging men become bald more at the crown, but turn grey more at the temples, because the crown is the driest of all parts of the head; for there the skin lies upon bare bone; but the temples are moister, for there are large muscles there beneath the skin, and every muscle is fleshy, and flesh is moister than bone and skin. VI. One must pay precise attention to what is being said, lest we inadvertently mishear something and err, just as many of those who seem to be the very best physicians err, thinking that if someone is bald, he immediately has a dry temperament of the entire body.

gemini.translation:
For it has been shown previously that all the parts of those growing old become dry. And in many people, the skin, having been dried out more than is necessary, becomes like earthenware. And in such skin, nothing is able to grow, just as has also been acknowledged through the preceding arguments. For indeed, the inner parts of the hands, just like the lower parts of the feet, are hairless and bare due to both the dryness and the density of the tendon in those areas, which is situated beneath the skin. But for all those in whom the skin of the head does not reach a state of complete dryness, the hairs become weak and invariably white—what people call gray hairs—weak, on the one hand, from a lack of their proper nourishment, and white, on the other, because that which nourishes them is of a quality like a kind of mold from phlegm that has putrefied over time. For whenever the pore still remains, but the residue is scant and viscous, and is pushed forward weakly by the heat, it undergoes something similar in this state of putrefaction. And so, as they grow old, people become bald more on the bregma, but go gray more on the temples, because the former is the driest of all the parts of the head (for in this area the skin is on bare bone), while the temples are moister (for here there are large muscles under the skin, and every muscle is fleshy, and flesh is moister than bone and skin).

VI. But one must apply one’s mind precisely to what is being said, so that we do not inadvertently mishear something and go astray, just as indeed many of those reputed to be the very best physicians go astray, by immediately supposing, if someone is bald, that this person has a dry temperament of the whole body.

claude.translation: And those in whom the nose is sharp and hooked are dry, but when it is snub-nosed they are moist; and the same applies concerning the eyes and the temples and all the other parts. But in those whose mixture is uneven and not the same in all parts, it is absurd in these cases to make a pronouncement about nature concerning all parts from a single part. Something of this sort has deceived most of them, who have dared to make pronouncements not only about human beings but also about other animals concerning the whole mixture from the signs in the skin alone. For neither if the skin is hard is the animal necessarily dry, but it is possible for the skin alone to be so, nor if it is black nor if it is hairy. And in the same way, neither if it is soft or white or bare of hair is the whole animal necessarily moist. But if the whole is blended uniformly, it is reasonable that, just as the skin is, so also is each of the other parts, but if it is blended unevenly, no longer. At any rate, in the case of oysters the whole body is most moist, but the skin is most dry; for indeed the shell is to them what the skin is to us. And the name comes from this, since all such animals have been called shell-skinned from having a skin similar to a shell. And the soft-shelled creatures also, such as lobsters and crayfish and crabs, have dry skin, but all the rest of their mixture is moist.

And the malacostracans too, such as lobsters, crayfish, and crabs, have a dry skin, but the entire rest of their temperament is moist.

But for those whose temperament is uneven and not the same in all their parts, it is absurd in these cases to make a pronouncement about the whole from the nature of a single part. But something of this sort has deceived most of them, who dared to make a pronouncement not only concerning humans but also about the other animals, regarding the entire temperament, on the basis of the characteristics of the skin alone. For an animal is not necessarily dry if its skin is hard—since it is possible for the skin alone to be so—nor if it is black, nor if it is hairy. And in the same way, not even if it is soft or white or bare of hair, is the whole animal necessarily moist. But if the whole is uniformly tempered, it is reasonable that each of the other parts is of the same sort as the skin; but if it is unevenly tempered, this is no longer the case. In the case of oysters, for instance, the whole body is most moist, but the skin is most dry. For their shell is just like our skin. And the name comes from this, since all such animals were named ostracoderms from the fact that they have skin similar to a shell. And the malacostracans too, such as lobsters, crayfish, and crabs, have a dry skin, but the entire rest of their temperament is moist.

A mistake of this sort has misled most of them, who have ventured to pronounce not only about human beings but also about other animals regarding the entire mixture on the basis solely of the signs furnished by the skin. For neither, if the skin is hard, is the animal of necessity dry—it may be only the skin—nor if it is dark or shaggy; and in the same way, neither, if it is soft or white or hairless, is the whole animal necessarily moist. claude.translation: And the drug of Medea was of such a nature. At any rate, everything to which it is applied bursts into flame when heat is brought near. That drug is prepared from sulfur and liquid asphalt. And indeed someone used to display it as a marvel: after extinguishing a lamp he would light it again by bringing it near a wall; another would bring it near a stone; for both the wall and the stone had been treated with sulfur. And when this was understood, what occurred was no longer marvelous. All these drugs, therefore, are not yet completely hot, but they are most suitable for becoming hot, and for this reason they are called potentially hot. Concerning these matters there is no difficulty, nor is there any difficulty about why wine, when drunk, sufficiently heats the body, but when applied to the skin does not heat it. For it has been shown a little earlier that it heats the living creature not simply as a hot drug but as proper nourishment. For just as suitable fuels for fire increase the fire, so too whatever is proper and natural nourishment for naturally hot bodies will certainly strengthen them and increase their innate heat. And this is common to all nourishment; but peculiar and distinctive to wine is the swiftness of its transformation, as with torches and lamp-wicks and tow and pitch. And indeed, keeping to the image of fire, let us recall again green wood, which is itself also fuel for fire, but not immediately or at once, and for this reason when placed upon the fire it conceals the flame, especially if it is weak and small, and brings danger of extinction.

gemini.translation:
And the drug of Medea was also of such a kind. For indeed, everything with which it might be smeared is ignited when heat is applied. And that substance is prepared from both sulfur and liquid asphalt. And indeed, someone was demonstrating it as a marvel: extinguishing a lamp, he would light it again by bringing it near a wall; and another would bring it near a stone. For, as it turned out, both the wall and the stone had been treated with sulfur. And when this became known, what was happening was no longer marvelous.

All these drugs, therefore, are not yet completely hot, but they are most suitable for becoming hot, and for this reason they are said to be potentially hot. Concerning these matters, then, there is no difficulty, nor as to why wine, when drunk, sufficiently heats the body, but when applied to the skin, does not heat it. For it has been shown a little earlier that it heats the living creature not simply as a hot drug but as a congenial nutriment. For just as the suitable nutriments for fire increase the fire, so also whatever is a congenial and connate nutriment for naturally hot bodies will in every way strengthen them and will increase their innate heat. And this, on the one hand, is common to all nutriment; but on the other hand, the speed of its transformation belongs to wine as a special and exceptional quality, as it does to a torch, a wick, tow, and pitch. And indeed, clinging to the image of fire, let us again call to mind damp wood, which is also itself a nutriment for fire, but not immediately nor instantly; and for this reason, when thrown upon the fire, it both conceals the flame—especially if the flame should be weak and small—and brings on the danger of its extinction.

openai.translation: And the drug of Medea was of such a sort. For, at any rate, everything is kindled when heat is applied to whatever has been smeared with it. That preparation is made by means of sulfur and liquid bitumen. Indeed, someone even used to exhibit it as a wonder: having extinguished a lamp, he would light it again by bringing it near a wall; another would bring it near a stone; and it turned out that both the wall and the stone had been sulfurized. Once this was recognized, the occurrence was no longer marvelous. All these drugs, then, are not yet completely hot, but are most apt to become hot; and for this reason they are said to be hot in potentiality. Concerning these matters there is nothing puzzling, nor about why wine, when drunk, sufficiently warms the body, whereas, when applied to the skin, it does not warm. For it has been shown a little earlier that it warms the animal not simply as a hot drug but as proper nourishment. For just as the suitable nutriments of fire increase the fire, so too, in the case of bodies naturally hot, whatever nutriment is proper and connatural will assuredly strengthen them and increase the innate heat. This is common to all nourishment; but peculiar and exceptional to wine is the speed of its transformation, as with a torch, a wick, tinder, and pitch. And, keeping to the image of fire, let us recall again wet wood, which is itself nutriment for fire, but not immediately nor on the instant; and for this reason, when it is thrown upon the fire, it both smothers the flame—especially if it happens to be weak and small—and brings the danger of extinction.

claude.translation: For if certain affections concerning us are so small throughout as to produce no perceptible and clear harm to any activity, they are surely to be despised and one must concede to him who asserts that such things do not even exist. Thus it stands also in the case of almost all nourishing substances. For they too produce some effect upon the human body, but not one that is perceptible or clear all at once. However, their prolonged consumption greatly alters and changes the bodies in a now clearly evident way. Some indeed even at their first use immediately show the alteration clearly, as for instance lettuce, which clearly cools and renders free from thirst those who are burning in the stomach, but evidently harms those who are chilled. It contributes not a little also to sleep, for no other reason than that it is cold and moist in its mixture, but so cold and moist in relation to man and all other things it is naturally suited to nourish as green wood is in relation to fire. Therefore it is reasonable that both properties belong to such foods: both to affect our bodies as drugs do and to nourish—throughout the whole time of digestion as drugs do; but when it already nourishes and is completely assimilated, then it no longer acts against us in any way, increasing the innate heat, as has been said before. For this is common to all nourishing substances, and one should not wonder if something, before being assimilated and nourishing, while still being digested, cooled, but once assimilated and having nourished, warmed—always remembering the example of green wood.

gemini.translation: For if certain affections upon us should be so small continually as to produce no perceptible and clear harm to any activity, they are, I suppose, easily disregarded, and one must concede to the one who asserts that such things do not even exist. And it contributes not a little to sleep for no other reason than that it is both cold and moist in its temperament; but it is cold and moist in relation to a human being and all other things that it is its nature to nourish in the same way as green wood is in relation to fire. So that it is reasonable that both properties belong to such foods: that of affecting our bodies as drugs do, and that of nourishing them. openai.translation: For if there are continually certain slight affections in relation to us, such that they produce no perceptible and distinct harm to any function, they are, of course, easily disregarded, and one must even concede to the person who claims that such things do not exist. Thus it is with almost all things that nourish. They too produce some effect upon the human body, but not at once in a perceptible or clear fashion. Yet their long-continued application greatly alters and now clearly transforms bodies. Some, to be sure, even on first use immediately display the alteration plainly—for example lettuce, which clearly revives and makes unthirsty those whose stomach is overheated, while manifestly harming those who are chilled. And it contributes not a little to sleep, for no other reason than that it is cold and moist in temperament—so cold and moist, in relation to a human being and to the other things that are by nature nourished, as green wood is in relation to fire. Accordingly, it is reasonable that both properties belong to foods of this sort: both that they dispose our bodies as drugs do and that they nourish—throughout the entire time of concoction, as by drugs; but when it already nourishes and is completely assimilated, then, with nothing in us reacting, it augments the innate heat, as has also been said before. For this is common to all things that nourish, and one ought not be surprised if anything, before being assimilated and nourishing, while still undergoing concoction, has cooled, but once assimilated and having nourished has warmed—always remembering the example of green wood.
